ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Bilateral Otosclerosis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Bilateral mixed hearing loss with Carhart notch at 2000 Hz, absent acoustic reflexes despite normal tympanograms, and Schwartze signs on otoscopy.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Noise-Induced Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of occupational noise exposure explains some sensorineural loss but not the conductive component, Carhart notch, or absent reflexes.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Otitis Media
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient attributed loss to recent infections, but ruled out by normal Type A tympanograms.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To determine the degree, type, and configuration of hearing loss.
To assess speech recognition thresholds and word recognition scores.
To evaluate middle ear function and rule out otitis media.
To assess the integrity of the reflex arc and check for stapes fixation.
To visualize the tympanic membrane for signs of otosclerosis (Schwartze sign).
To evaluate the temporal bone and confirm otosclerosis or rule out other pathologies.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiological evaluation reveals bilateral symmetric mixed hearing loss with a characteristic Carhart notch at 2000 Hz. Despite normal tympanograms, acoustic reflexes are absent, strongly suggesting otosclerosis.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral symmetric moderate rising to mild mixed hearing loss (250-3000 Hz), sloping to moderate conductive loss at 4000 Hz. Carhart notch present at 2000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs align with pure tone averages (45 dB HL). WRS are excellent (100% at 80 dB HL) bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Absent at 500-4000 Hz for both ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Otologic consultation confirms the diagnosis of otosclerosis through microscopic visualization of Schwartze signs and CT imaging showing questionable oval window otosclerosis.

tests.name: Microscopic otoscopy
tests.result_summary: Revealed bilateral Schwartze signs (reddish hue on promontory).

tests.name: CT scan
tests.result_summary: Showed no temporal bone abnormalities but questionable oval window otosclerosis.

proposed_items: Referral to otologist for medical/surgical evaluation
counseling_actions: Explain the diagnosis of otosclerosis and the mechanism of conductive hearing loss (stapes fixation)
Discuss management options including surgery (stapedotomy/stapedectomy) versus amplification (hearing aids)
Advise on the importance of hearing protection given the history of noise exposure
Discuss the potential for bilateral progression

escalation.rationale_short: For evaluation of mixed hearing loss and consideration of surgical intervention for otosclerosis.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor post-surgical healing, assess hearing improvement, and determine management for the non-surgical ear.

expected_outcome: Left stapedotomy was performed without complications.
Patient experienced mild initial imbalance post-surgery which subsided by the 1-month follow-up.
Patient reported marked improvement in hearing in the left ear and declined surgery on the right ear.
Patient did not return for the 3-month follow-up appointment, so no post-operative audiometric data is available.
